head.title: Free of Missteps And of Suspense

hedline.hl1: Free of Missteps And of Suspense

abstract.p: Several Milwaukee residents share their thoughts on Republican National Convention; photo (M)

block.p: Watching the Republican National Convention from his living room, James Greer, a 54-year-old lawyer and an independent, found himself awash in pleasantness.
It was Laura Bush, the wife of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who set the tone. ''She has a softer way,'' Mr. Greer said. ''She's really a plus.''
Watching the Republican National Convention from his living room, James Greer, a 54-year-old lawyer and an independent, found himself awash in pleasantness.
It was Laura Bush, the wife of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who set the tone. ''She has a softer way,'' Mr. Greer said. ''She's really a plus.''
Like movie critics, or perhaps Olympic judges, Mr. Greer and five other Milwaukee residents watched the convention, giving marks for style and substance, ready to catch any stumbles.
In the end, all of them -- a die-hard Republican, a devoted Democrat and varying shades of independents -- agreed that while the convention was lacking in suspense, it was also free of missteps.
On Monday night, one resident, Brian Colon, 27, a computer programmer, found comfort in Gen. Colin L. Powell's message that many Americans deserved help.
Another resident, Chiquita Lee, a 63-year-old homemaker and a Republican, who is black, found it pleasing to watch Republicans ''of different colors -- this convention was really reaching out.''
Paris Wright, a 36-year-old computer systems analyst, also expressed approval that Republicans ''realize that demographics are changing, and that they need to widen the umbrella.''

On the other hand, Kathleen Wyman, a 59-year-old real estate agent, found the efforts at racial diversity a bit forced. ''Are these people really representative of the new Republicans?'' Ms. Wyman asked, muffling a chuckle. ''Of course they're not.''

And for Carolyn Castore, 47, who works for a nonprofit organization, the feel-good tenor of the opening night was lacking in substance. ''It's like baby food,'' Ms. Castore, a Democrat, said, ''no flavor, no texture and designed to be easily swallowed.''
On the convention's second night, Mr. Greer offered praise as he listened to speeches by Senator John McCain of Arizona and Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's chief international affairs adviser.
''One thing Republicans do well is patriotism,'' Mr. Greer said. ''They have a knack for waving the flag.''
Mr. Colon, so impressed by Mr. McCain, exclaimed, ''I wish I had this on tape!''

But others were not convinced that Mr. McCain was speaking from his heart. ''McCain gives a very good speech,'' Ms. Wyman said, ''but I would bet that in his heart of hearts, he doesn't believe what he says about Bush.''

Ms. Lee was taken with Lynne Cheney, the wife of Dick Cheney, the vice-presidential candidate. ''She showed her devotion and love for her husband,'' she said, ''while still showing that she was her own person.''
For Mr. Wright, it was the tribute to past presidents, especially Ronald Reagan, that rang bells. ''It was really very moving,'' he said.
On Wednesday night, when Mr. Cheney introduced himself to voters, the reviews from the Milwaukee residents were mostly favorable but hardly inspired.
Ms. Lee found Mr. Cheney's speech to be a bit heavy on cliches. ''I think he has to grow on you,'' she said.
Mr. Colon said, ''It was just a speech, not so good, not so bad.''
But Ms. Wyman found Mr. Cheney's talk to be ''rational and to the point.'' ''I can see this ticket being very attractive,'' she said.

Ms. Castore said Mr. Cheney's speech was intended to shore up the conservative base. ''Until he spoke, the messages had been so progressive, that I was starting to feel sorry for the Republicans,'' she said. ''But Cheney, with the whole morality issue, seemed to be bringing back the base.''
The Milwaukee residents paid most attention, not surprisingly, to the speech by Mr. Bush on Thursday night. Most considered the speech a success.
Mr. Bush ''looked presidential,'' Ms. Wyman said, and he ''comes across better than his father ever did.''
In some places, she said, it was almost Reaganesque, ''the way he talked about real people and made things very clear.''
Mr. Greer noted that Mr. Bush ''didn't have his smirk,'' and said the candidate scored points by presenting himself ''as a human,'' especially when making references to his mother.
Ms. Lee remarked at Mr. Bush's ''charisma, the friend-next-door appeal,'' and applauded his plans on education.

For Ms. Castore, the praise was grudging. ''As a speech it was O.K., but I thought his attacks on Gore fell flat,'' she said, referring to Vice President Al Gore. ''A lot of what he said, it sounded good. But I don't know what it means. It lacked so many specifics.''
But for Mr. Colon, who had started the week not certain whether he would vote for Mr. Bush or not, the speech was a clincher.
''I just loved it,'' Mr. Colon said. ''I'm ready to march right out and vote for him.''
Dirk Johnson
THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE IMPRESSIONS -- MILWAUKEE
